question.questionA: Sepals five to six, fused into a tube.
question.questionB: Sepals four to five, free.

question.questionA: Styles three to five.
question.questionB: Styles two.

question.questionA: Calyx much longer than petals.
question.questionB: Calyx shorter than petals; if petals absent, then seeds with undulate wings.

question.questionA: Perennials.
question.questionB: Annuals

question.questionA: Woody plants, softly pubescent; calyx hairy, not inflated.
question.questionB: Herbaceous plants, usually glabrous; calyx glabrous, inflated.

question.questionA: Seeds with undulate wings
question.questionB: Seeds wingless.

question.questionA: Leaves almost glabrous; petals conspicuous.
question.questionB: Leaves pubescent; petals small or often absent.

question.questionA: Hispid plants;  inflorescence  subcapitate; petals  scarcely  longer  than sepals.
question.questionB: Inflorescence  not  subcapitate;  petals  usually  distinctly  longer  than sepals.

question.questionA: Flowers solitary.
question.questionB: Flowers in groups of two or more.

question.questionA: Flowers axillary.
question.questionB: Flowers terminal.

question.questionA: Petals little longer than calyx.
question.questionB: Petals distinctly longer than calyx.

question.questionA: Leaves with undulate margins; petals bright red.
question.questionB: Leaf margins not undulate; petals pale pink.

question.questionA: Plants  not  viscid; leaves and stems green; calyx with prominent anastomosing veins.
question.questionB: Plants viscid; stems, leaf-tips and veins of calyx often red; calyx with prominent parallel veins.

question.questionA: Plants viscid; petals dark pink, entire.
question.questionB: Plants pubescent; petals pale pink, bifid.

question.questionA: Plants viscid; flowers in axillary pairs.
question.questionB: Flowers in cymes of three or more.

question.questionA: Plants viscid; petals not much longer than the calyx, white, notched.
question.questionB: Plants softly hairy; petals almost twice the length of the calyx, pale pink, bifid.

question.questionA: Epicalyx of several scales present; petals without scales at the throat.
question.questionB: Epicalyx absent; petals with scales at the throat.

question.questionA: Fruit a capsule, splitting by teeth or valves.
question.questionB: Fruit not splitting, or splitting but remaining joined above.

question.questionA: Leaves often whorled or clustered; stipules scarious.
question.questionB: Leaves opposite; stipules absent.

question.questionA: Flowers white or pink, more than 5 mm across.
question.questionB: Flowers white, less than 5 mm across.

question.questionA: Robust perennials; petals c. 5mm, at least as long as sepals.
question.questionB: Annuals.

question.questionA: Leaves linear; petals pink, white towards the base, not exceeding the sepals; capsule usually exceeding calyx.
question.questionB: Leaves fasciculate; petals uniformly pink, at least as long as calyx; capsule about equalling calyx.

question.questionA: Leaves in whorls of four; inflorescences lax.
question.questionB: Leaves in opposite pairs; inflorescences very compact.

question.questionA: Leaves fleshy; stipules small and greyish.
question.questionB: Leaves not fleshy; stipules prominent, silvery.

question.questionA: Petals absent.
question.questionB: Petals present.

question.questionA: Leaves linear.
question.questionB: Leaves not linear.

question.questionA: Loosely branched annuals, usually slightly hairy; leaves aristate.
question.questionB: Densely branched annuals, usually glabrous; leaves not aristate.

question.questionA: Annuals; petals half the length of the sepals.
question.questionB: Perennials; petals more than twice the length of the sepals.

question.questionA: Leaves linear; petals elliptical.
question.questionB: Leaves ovate; petals almost as broad as long.

question.questionA: Sepals ovate
question.questionB: Sepals lanceolate.

question.questionA: Petals deeply two-lobed.
question.questionB: Petals entire, or shallowly notched.

question.questionA: Styles four to five; fruit with eight or ten teeth.
question.questionB: Styles three; fruit with six valves or teeth.

question.questionA: Flowers in compact clusters; pedicels shorter than calyx.
question.questionB: Flowers in lax cymes; pedicels at least as long as calyx.

question.questionA: Petals less than half the length of the sepals.
question.questionB: Petals more than half the length of the calyx.

question.questionA: Petals bifid.
question.questionB: Petals notched.

question.questionA: Lower leaves with long petioles, upper usually sessile; petals deeply bifid, usually shorter than sepals.
question.questionB: All leaves usually petiolate; petals minute or absent.

question.questionA: Styles as many as sepals.
question.questionB: Styles fewer than sepals.

question.questionA: Leaves linear.
question.questionB: Leaves oval.

question.questionA: Annuals, eglandular pubescent.
question.questionB: Perennials, glandular pubescent.

question.questionA: Leaves less than 1 cm long.
question.questionB: Leaves more than 1 cm long.

question.questionA: Bracts inconspicuous.
question.questionB: Bracts usually silvery and longer than flowers.

question.questionA: Procumbent perennial; flowers in axillary clusters.
question.questionB: Erect tufted perennial; flowers in terminal clusters
